--- title: "2.7 — The Political Economy of Trade Policy — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Date *Thursday, April 13, 2023* ::: ## Overview Today, we look at the politics of trade policy, examining how different groups in a modern democracy have different objectives and face different incentives, culminating in trade policy that concentrates benefits and disperses costs. The tools we use are standard in [“public choice”](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_choice) analysis — the economic analysis of politics. You can learn more in [my public economics course](https://publics20.classes.ryansafner.com). ### Readings ### Required Readings: - [ Caplan, 2007, "The Myth of the Rational Voter"](/files/readings/Caplan-2007.pdf) - [ Somin, 2014, "When Ignorance Isn't Bliss"](/files/readings/Somin-2014.pdf) - [ Buchanan, 1984, "Politics Without Romance"](/files/readings/Buchanan-1984.pdf) - [ Mitchell, 2013, "The Pathology of Privilege: The Economic Consequences of Government Favoritism"](/files/readings/Mitchell-2013.pdf) ### Optional Readings - [ Grossman and Helpman, 1994, "Protection for Sale"](/files/readings/Grossman-Helpman-1994.pdf) - [ Baldwin and Magee, 2000, "Is trade policy for sale? Congressional voting on recent t?"](/files/readings/Baldwin-Magee-2000.pdf) ### Helpful: - [ Public Choice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_choice) - [ The Logic of Collective Action](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Logic_of_Collective_Action) - [ Government failure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_failure) - [ Rational ignorance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_ignorance) - [ Rent seeking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rent_seeking) - [ Regulatory capture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_capture) ### Questions To Help Your Reading - Why is good governance a public good, subject to a free rider problem? - What is “rational ignorance”? - What is Caplan’s idea of “rational irrationality” and how is it different from “rational ignorance?” - According to Caplan, what are the four systematic biases? - Why do people vote or not vote? How do people that do vote choose how they vote? - What is the principle of “concentrated benefits and dispersed costs?” ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!
